Award.AwardTitle: Fundamental Properties of Saloplastic Polyelectrolyte Complexes
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL:

Polyelectrolytes are water-soluble, charged polymers used in products ranging from shampoos to water purification treatments. If solutions of polyelectrolytes with opposite charges are mixed they precipitate into complexes that are biocompatible, rugged, elastic blends of the individual polymers. These complexes have potential medical applications in extended drug delivery and replacement for cartilage. They are also useful as membranes for water purification and desalination. Although their synthesis is straightforward, it has been impossible to process them into useful forms using heat softening, as is used for the more familiar "thermoplastics". This project will explore novel, versatile methods for softening and processing polyelectrolyte complexes using salt water instead of heat. Softening by adding salt, termed "saloplasticity", is a new technique that lowers energy consumption for polymer processing. Because it is performed with no volatile organic solvents it is also environmentally friendly. Several fundamental questions will be explored in this project: how do blends of different polymers respond to different salts? How is elasticity, essential for mimicking the properties of cartilage, controlled by salt? How can additional strength be built into saloplastics so they will last when used as replacements for intervertebral discs? At the same time these fundamental materials properties questions are explored, the project will support and promote international collaborations with the University of Strasbourg, France. Among the educational aspects of this project will also be a collaboration between the College of Business and the Department of Chemistry at Florida State University wherein Entrepreneurship and Chemistry students team up to write commercialization plans for technology developed by this and other projects.


TECHNICAL:

Polyelectrolytes are water-soluble, charged polymers used in products ranging from shampoos to water purification treatments. If solutions of polyelectrolytes with opposite charges are mixed they precipitate into complexes that are biocompatible, rugged, viscoelastic blends of the individual polymers. Unlike traditional thermoplastics, polyelectrolyte complexes, PECs, cannot be processed when dry by heat softening. Instead, they may be plasticized with salt water. Increasing salt concentration progressively breaks the ionic pairing between polyelectrolytes. This "saloplasticity" is used along with heating to control the viscoelasticity of PECs. The overarching goal of this project is to probe the fundamental ways salt and heat are related to the properties of saloplastics. In the first of four subtopics, the glass transition, or softening temperature, of different pairs of polyelectrolytes with different strengths of interaction will be probed. The second part will look at the processing response of blends versus copolymers having the same composition. The next subtopic will attempt to answer fundamental questions about the role of molecular weight in saloplastic viscoelasticity. Finally, additional chemical crosslinks will be built into bulk saloplastics to stabilize the material for long-term use in biomedical applications such as artificial cartilage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Charged polymers, polyelectrolytes, are found everywhere in nature and also in manufactured products consumed daily, such as shampoo and other personal care items. When polyelectrolytes with opposite charges are mixed they associate. The resulting material, represented in Figure 1, called a complex or coacervate, is rubbery or viscous with many existing or potential applications.

Complexes/coacervates are used extensively in food manufacturing to produce gums and viscous solutions. This project explored a fascinating property of complexes: added salt breaks apart the associations between polymers, shown in Figure 1, which softens the material, a property known as "saloplasticity."

This project continued our exploration into the salt-modified properties of complexes in the form of large pieces and as thin film coatings. Thin films of complex have been used for water purification and filtration. We showed, in this project, how polyelectrolyte within a film can react with an oppositely-charged polymer in solution.  The reacting partners diffuse towards the interface (Figure 2) and react there. To understand the process we needed to measure the diffusion rate of a charged polymer within a charged polymer, which had not been done before.

Removing excess polymer of one charge, shown in Figure 2, allows the thin film to become more selective when it is used as a membrane, leading to improved purification.

We exploited the "saloplastic" properties of complexes to create large articles (sheets, tapes, rods, tubes) which, when hydrated, have viscoelastic, shock-absorbing properties. Many researchers in the field have noticed that complexes become porous when salt is extracted from them by washing them in pure water. We discovered the mechanism, shown in Figure 3. When the salt escapes it brings water with it. Instead of going into solution, as the salt does, the extra water consolidates into pores.

While the number of polyelectrolytes available to synthesize complexes is large and increasing, the corresponding number of positive and negative polyelectrolyte combinations is vast. In this project, the binding strengths between a selection of positive and negative polyelectrolytes were quantitatively compared by evaluating the extent to which ion pairs between them are broken by a common salt, KBr.

A selection of commercially available, low-cost, water-soluble polyelectrolytes allowed comparisons of aromatic versus aliphatic, carboxylate compared to sulfonate, alkyl ammonium with amine and a range of charge densities (defined either as the number of backbone carbons per charged unit or the repeat unit volume). The range of differences in association strength observed will guide future development of materials with appropriate mechanical and chemical properties.

Broader Impacts

Several graduate students as well as undergraduates benefitted from the interdisciplinary environment of this project. PhD graduates have gone on to secure permanent positions at Intel, GE Healthcare, Fujifilm, and Avery Dennison. There is now a much better understanding of how to prepare and process complexes into useful materials. Because of our success in the field, we are now engaged in a collaboration with Procter and Gamble, a company that makes extensive use of polyelectrolytes and complexes. Industries in the contact lens and adhesives field have also been updated by presentations on our latest research. The possibility of forming and reforming different articles from the same materials, just by adding salt, is a promising dimension for reducing plastic waste by efficient recycling.
